description: A TEP is a device that is placed into a surgically created fistula in the shared wall that connects the posterior wall of the trachea and the anterior wall of the esophagus.(1) This wall is referred to as the “party wall.”(1) Such a fistula is referred to as a tracheoesophageal puncture.(2) When the patient’s stoma (the opening in the neck following a laryngectomy through which a patient breathes) is covered, expiratory air is directed from the lungs through the TEP into the esophagus, vibrating the pharyngoesophageal segment and surrounding tissues to create a sound source for speech.(1,2,3,4,5,6) TEPs are one-way  valves that prevent the puncture from sealing up and also keep food and liquid out of the trachea(3,5)
indications: A TEP is indicated for a patient who has had his or her larynx removed due to laryngeal cancer or severe trauma.(7) The surgery to remove the larynx is referred to as laryngectomy.(8,9) A laryngectomee is a person who has undergone larynx removal.(8) Following surgery to remove the larynx, a laryngectomee is unable to produce a normal voice.(10) Additionally, the person can no longer breathe through his or her nose or mouth, and hence breathes via a stoma in the neck.(10) Using the TEP to create a laryngeal speech is considered the best method of voice rehabilitation following laryngectomy per current research because it creates a pseudo-voice  most like a normal voice that is more easily understood than esophageal or artificial larynx speech(5,11)
For detailed information on laryngectomy, see Clinical Review…Laryngectomy, Total ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708744 and Clinical Review…Laryngectomy, Partial ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708836

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified Indications for device/equipment
contraindications precautions to test: Communicate with the patient’s doctor to determine if the patient’s neck may be palpated during examination

Patients who have undergone laryngectomy are at an increased risk for depression due to the complete loss of voice.(20,21) If signs of depression (such as lethargy, hopelessness, crying) or grieving are noted, a referral should be made to psychiatry or psychology(22)

Although the placement of TEP is within the scope of practice of an SLP, additional special knowledge and skills are required(2,3,23) –The education that is required prior to placing and/or replacing TEPs and treating patients with a TEP can be acquired through classes or gained over time in a clinical setting while working with a more experienced SLP(3,23) –State licensure boards might require additional certification for SLPs who work with TEPs;(3) refer to individual state licensing boards –Please refer to the ASHA Technical Report and Knowledge and Skills paper for a very specific outline of skills necessary in treating this population(3,23)

contraindications precautions to examina: Communicate with the patient’s doctor to determine if the patient’s neck may be palpated during examination

Patients who have undergone laryngectomy are at an increased risk for depression due to the complete loss of voice.(20,21) If signs of depression (such as lethargy, hopelessness, crying) or grieving are noted, a referral should be made to psychiatry or psychology(22)

Although the placement of TEP is within the scope of practice of an SLP, additional special knowledge and skills are required(2,3,23) –The education that is required prior to placing and/or replacing TEPs and treating patients with a TEP can be acquired through classes or gained over time in a clinical setting while working with a more experienced SLP(3,23) –State licensure boards might require additional certification for SLPs who work with TEPs;(3) refer to individual state licensing boards –Please refer to the ASHA Technical Report and Knowledge and Skills paper for a very specific outline of skills necessary in treating this population(3,23)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: How did the patient lose his or her larynx? As a result of a total or partial laryngectomy to treat cancer? As a result of trauma? When was the surgery to remove the larynx performed?

course of treatment.medical management: Note whether the patient has received radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of the two for cancer. Is the patient currently receiving treatment for cancer?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: It is important to consider the time that has lapsed since the patient’s most recent chemotherapy or radiation treatment as this will considerably affect pain levels. Patients who have undergone laryngectomy often have ongoing issues with gastroesophageal reflux. Although it has been proposed that reflux is associated with complications of a TE fistula and a TEP, researchers who conducted a study in Croatia with 41 participants found no statistically significant correlation between reflux and complications with TE fistula or TEP(43)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms, which includes changes in smell or taste(10) -Does blood or secretions leak from the patient’s stoma?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physicianPatients who have had a laryngectomy are at significant risk for depression due to grief over the loss of their previous life and function.(22) It is important to assess how well the patient is coping with this significant change and make referrals to psychiatry/counseling if necessary(22) -Briefly engage the patient in a discussion regarding his or her ability to cope with the laryngectomy -If the patient is overly emotional or describes difficulty managing his or her feelings related to the laryngectomy, a referral to psychiatry/counseling may be appropriate
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document if the patient requires supplemental oxygen. Does the patient have difficulty breathing through the stoma? Note stomal competency, skin breakdown, or excessive secretions. Does the patient use a heat and moisture exchanger (HME)?(10) -HMEs are devices that cover the stoma and help to retain appropriate levels of heat and moisture inside the trachea which can be used in conjunction with a TEP(10,15,17) -HMEs can be used to improve respiratory status by increasing the temperature and the moisture retention of pulmonary mucosa -In a study conducted in the Netherlands with 3 subjects, fewer respiratory problems and improvements in upper airway mucosa were noted following a 6-week  trial with an HME(10) -The HMEs also appear to improve maximum phonation time and speech intelligibility(5,10,24) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient ever used a TEP before? Has the patient used another form of alaryngeal communication, such as esophageal speech or tracheoesophageal speech?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including dysphagia, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: (include limitations with self-care, home management, work, community leisure). Does the patient require a hearing aid? If so, is it in good working order? Does the patient wear glasses? Does the patient require a cane or walker?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does patient live (e.g., family, caregivers)? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document the use of any assistive devices for ambulation, ADLs, or communication. Laryngectomees might already be utilizing an alternative method of communication, such as pen and paper(20)
observation inspection palpation includi: It is important to assess the laryngectomee’s stoma for excessive secretions and skin breakdown as well as appropriate stoma size (if stoma stenosis occurs, it may affect the patient’s breathing)(10,27)

Additionally, patients with deep, large, or small stomas or necks with significant scar tissue or edema are especially challenging to fit with a TEP due to difficulty with adhesion to the skin or reduced access to the tracheoesophageal puncture(6,24) •Oral mechanism exam:  In order for a laryngectomee to produce intelligible speech with a TEP, the articulators (tongue, lips, teeth) should be functioning normally(8,10,20,28)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Can the laryngectomee adequately care for his or her stoma? The patient will have to use swabs or washcloths daily to wipe the skin around the stoma to prevent crusty buildup of mucous or blood. Some patients require suctioning devices if they produce a lot of secretions. If the patient appears to have excess buildup of secretions or reports difficulty cleaning his or her stoma, refer patient to his physician and/or occupational therapy
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisIn order to produce vibrations to be used as a voice, the pharyngoesophageal segment must be tonic.(5) Hyper-  or hypotonicity of the pharyngoesophageal segment can result in an inability to create a pseudo-voice  with the TEP.(6,16,24) Tests to ensure that the patient has adequate pharyngoesophageal tonicity include a modified barium swallow study, attempted phonation via TEP or esophageal speech, and the esophageal insufflation test.(5,6,29,30) In an esophageal insufflation test, air is injected into the pharyngoesophageal segment via a catheter thread down through the nose.(29,30) A positive insufflation test results in sound being produced from the pharyngoesophageal segment; when there is no sound or abnormal sound, the result is said to be negative.(29) If the patient does not appear to have adequate pharyngoesophageal tonicity, refer to the surgeon regarding possible myotomy (surgery to cut the pharyngoesophageal muscle), neurectomy (surgery to remove part of a nerve that controls tonicity), or Botox treatments(5,6,16) –Voice assessment -Once the TEP has been placed, complete an assessment of the voice that the patient is able to produce. Possible voicesustaining a vowel /a/ for as long as possible on one breath; use the longest of three attempts(42)to be used as an estimate of speech-breathing  coordination; ask the patient to count up from one on a single deep breath with a natural pace; use the best of three attempts(42)can be performed with a computer and software designed to analyze vocal signals; analysis can include sustained /a/, bisyllabic words, and pitch-changing contours(42)patient is asked to read a passage at a comfortable loudness level and pitch and the clinician rates various aspects of the voice (e.g., roughness, breathiness, volume) on a given scale (e.g., normal, mild, moderate, severe)(42)Especially important for laryngectomees as they are at an elevated risk for depression due to the complete loss of their own voice.(20,21) The quality of life assessments should be made prior to beginning TEP use as well as several weeks or months after the patient has started using the device to ensure that the TEP is making a positive impact on quality of life.(31) In a study of satisfaction/quality of life in 42 laryngectomees in Italy who used a TEP, researchers found that although some aspects of quality of life improved with TEP, there were still negative effects, including social embarrassment and difficulty being understood on the telephone.(31) Quality of life measures appropriate -Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Scale(32) -Short Form 36-Item  Health Survey (SF-36)(33) -University of Washington Quality of Life Scale(32) -V oice Handicap Index (VHI)(34)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: It is important to assess cognitive abilities in laryngectomy patients in order to determine the most appropriate voice substitution method.(22,25) Patients with impaired cognition are not good candidates for TEP use. The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is an appropriate assessment tool to screen for arousal, attention, and other cognitive deficits. The MMSE assesses overall cognitive impairment; sections include Orientation to Time, Orientation to Place, Registration, Attention and Calculation, Recall, Naming, Repetition, Comprehension, Reading, Writing, Drawing(26)

contraindications precautions: Additionally, to prevent closure of the tracheoesophageal puncture, a stent or replacement TEP should be placed into the fistula immediately(37) ›Diagnosis/need for device/equipment:  Following an evaluation of the patient, the SLP and the laryngectomee must decide together on the best course of treatment.(9,10,17,22) Even if the TEP is determined to be the appropriate device for post-laryngectomy  speech, selection of the type of TEP (i.e., indwelling or hands-free)  is based on results of a thorough evaluation(17)
other: Intensive therapy for laryngectomees should not begin until internal sutures have healed; this process takes about 2 weeks(20)
A physician order is necessary prior to placing the TEP and beginning speech therapy

Dislodgement of valve with subsequent leakage of food and liquid into the trachea is a common complication of TEP use; however, therapists should be aware that tumor recurrence at the site of the TEP (the party wall between the esophagus and trachea) may be the cause of frequent dislodgements.(4) If during the course of treatment dislodgements, valve malfunctions, or pneumonias occur frequently, refer patient to his or her surgeon or oncologist for further workup
If granulation tissue is noted on the TEP, refer to surgeon/oncologist for management and for tissue testing to rule out tumor recurrence(6)
If patient reports losing the TEP, refer him or her to the emergency room immediately to determine if the TEP was aspirated into the lungs(35,36)
See Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above
contraindications precautions.general: Following an evaluation of the patient, the SLP and the laryngectomee must

prognosis: In a study conducted in Turkey with 32 male patients, researchers found that neither neck dissection nor radiation therapy had a significant influence on the quality of short-term  speech success with a TEP(38)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: If signs of depression or grieving are noted, a referral should be made to psychology or psychiatry.(22) In the case of stomal stenosis or difficulty breathing, refer the patient to his or her ENT surgeon for revision of the stoma.(27) Refer to ENT surgeon in the case of negative esophageal insufflation test results for management(5)
treatment summary: Speech intelligibility strategies –Contextual cues have been shown to aid listener comprehension of tracheoesophageal speech;(3) the SLP can train the patient to use gestures or writing of keywords to improve speech intelligibility –Due to the unnatural-sounding  tracheoesophageal voice, exaggerated articulatory movements may improve speech intelligibility; the SLP will educate the patient on how to make appropriately exaggerated articulatory movements; the patient then practices exaggerated articulatory movements in syllables, with word lists, sentences, and eventually conversational speech –Research has also linked improved speech intelligibility with longer duration of phonation.(3,4) The SLP can train the patient to improve duration of phonation by increasing breath support and/or learning breath support exercises

Singing therapy : In a study conducted in Brazil with 5 patients, researchers found that a singing training program improved voice quality with the TEP. For the study protocol, each patient participated in weekly, 30-minute  sessions for 12 weeks. Sessions followed a hierarchical structure with (1) exercises for strengthening respiratory muscles (e.g., inhaling fast/exhaling slow, then inhaling slowly and exhaling fast); (2) vocalization exercises on a musical scale of eight notes (do, re, mi, fa, so, la, ti, do). At the conclusion of 12 weeks, all of the participants demonstrated maintenance of or improvement in the degree of dysphonia, as well as the roughness and breathiness of the voice. V ocal extension (i.e., pitch range) improved in all patients, but did not match the range of a person with intact vocal folds(44)

Troubleshooting TEP –Leakage around the TEP valve or TEP can result from widening of the fistula or thinning of the party wall.(4,5,39)If this is the suspected cause, refer to the patient’s surgeon -Leakage related to widening of the fistula significantly increases risk of pneumonia in patients with TEP and should be managed immediately(40) –Leakage through the one-way  valve can result from damage to the valve mechanism from biofilm formation, fungal colonization (such as Candida  organisms), or damage from very vigorous cleaning(4,5,6,15) -In order to prevent the growth of bacteria or fungi, the patient is educated to regularly clean the TEP.(4,17) Additionally, some TEPs are designed to be “extended use,” resisting bacteria for longer periods of time(18) -In addition to ensuring that the TEP is clean, the SLP must also examine the valve mechanism itself to rule out a faulty TEP as the reason for the leakage(5) –Leakage around the prosthesis can also be due to incorrect TEP size.(14)If this is the problem, resizing the prosthesis will correct this issue; the SLP may re-attempt placement with a different sized prosthesis -In a study conducted in the Netherlands with 32 patients, researchers found high rates of success with eliminating leakage around the TEP by placing a thin silicone washer (0.5 mm thick and 18 mm in diameter) behind the tracheal flange of the TEP(41) –Leakage can also be due to the TEP reaching the end of its natural lifespan (3–6 months).(6)In this case, leakage can be corrected by replacing the TEP with a new one ›See Description, Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Reduced intelligibility of speechPatient will use speech intelligibility strategiesSpeech intelligibility strategies _ See Treatment summary , aboveProgression will vary according to patient goals, motivation, and premorbid communication skills; generally progression occurs from the least complex level of communication (e.g., words) and the SLP guides the patient through exercises involving increasing complex tasksThe SLP will determine an appropriate home program for TEP use Leakage of food/liquid/ saliva from esophagus into the tracheaReduce the amount of leakage through or around the TEP valve or TEPTroubleshooting TEP _ See Treatment summary , aboveLeakage through or around the TEP should be eliminated completelyLeakage management programs should be implemented at home; the SLP will educate the patient, family, and caregiver regarding proper routines .

improved quality of life: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Scale(32)
University of Washington Quality of Life Scale(32)

maintenance or prevention: TEP must be kept clean in order to stay in proper working order. Patients who have excessive stomal secretions should clean their TEPs more often
TEPs must be changed every 3–6 months.(4,15,18)Refer to manufacturer’s guidelines for the expected lifespan of the patient’s specific brand of TEP
patient education: Laryngectomees may find support and resources, as well as assistance in developing or improving alaryngeal speech, at the International Association of Laryngectomees website, https://theial.com/ial/

WebWhispers ( http://www.webwhispers.org/index.asp ) is an International Internet support group for laryngectomees Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
